Iodine from tincture is sooo much easier and waaay cheaper. Get two bottlers of tincture. 30ml of 31.45% HCl, 120ml of 3% H2O2. Put the HCl in first, and swirl around. Will look like wine. Then add the H2O2, swirl around. To avoid using as coffee filter and trying to scrape the iodine off, just watch the reaction flask for about 1 or 2 minutes. At this point, the iodine will be on the bottom. Just decant. Then dump the wet iodine into another flask that has a stopper. NOW, get a coffee filter and into it, put a tablespoon of MgSO4 (anhydrous). (You make this by putting Epsom salt into the oven at 300 degrees f until it turns white and flaky.) Tie the coffee filter like a tea bag and hang it in the flask with the wet iodine so the flask is closed but the tea bag isn't touching the bottom. If you don't wait too long to decant the liquid off the settled iodine, you wont even have to sublime. After the MgSO4 does its work, your iodine will be nice sparkly crystals already.

In the EU (speaking for Germany) this is now actually a reasonable way to obtain iodine. Shipping pure iodine is now banned but not because it's a meth precursor (like in the US), but - hold on - it *MAY* damage the thyroid gland if ingested in bulk. Most substances banned from shipping to private individuals are because of toxicity/carcinogenity or oxidizing power, seldom because they are drug precursor. The EU is just really paranoid when it comes to carcinogens, even if the carcinogenity is just remotely suspected.

You can still buy all kinds of toxic substances locally in a shop if it is near you and you are over 18 years old.

15:05 yeah yeah yeah, who cares. When are we gonna see you make re-sublimated thiotimoline?

In the thiotimoline molecule, there is at least one carbon atom such that, while two of the carbon's four chemical bonds lie in normal space and time, one of the bonds projects into the future and another into the past. Thiotimoline is derived from the bark of the shrub Rosacea karlsbadensis rugo, and the thiotimoline molecule includes at least fourteen hydroxy groups, two amino groups, and one sulfonic acid group, and possibly one nitro compound group as well. The nature of the hydrocarbon nucleus is unknown, although it seems in part to be an aromatic hydrocarbon.

It's one of the most crappy practices to collect purified Iodine on paper. Getting iodine from tincture is MUCH better, its faster and yields are better. You can usually get around 1 gram for every 1 oz of tincture.

When you distill the iodine, put the beaker in hot water up to its rim (put an inert weight in to keep it from floating) and put ice water in the flask on top.  ALL the iodine will distill to the flask in one go, and none will be left on the beaker.  If you are below 100C, the iodine will be truly be subliming. both from the beaker, and to the bottom of the flask.

The decrease in solubility of the povidone is going to be due to the fact you no longer have it as a salt after stealing the iodine from it, also I suppose it could possibly even cross link a bit, but not extensively considering sterics don't look particularly favourable, and excess base would probably attack that ketone more readily if any of that is going on. The fact that it's soluble to start means the chain length cant be particularly long even if it is as the salt, despite the oxygens there's enough aliphatic stuff going on to make it want to precipitate without many repeat units, probably even with only one of each. So yea, it's probably entirely because its no longer as the iodide.

The effect during filtering is happening because two very similiar liquids are combined and it is a very useful shortcut for comparing liquids without actually making an analysis. The film building between the two liquids happens at the atomic level and is caused by a sort of boiling one substance into another.

The "weird effect" around 6:20 is probably because of the basic nature of the solution. Bases tend to have a soapy feel to them, which affects the surface tension such that, when circumstances are right (such as the droplet size and height that they're falling from being just right) droplets can slide around on top of the liquid before the droplet merges with the main volume of the solution.
